pageTitle: Bubba Watson wins Masters in playoff - SFGate
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {96094=Bubba Watson of the US celebrates winning the 76th Masters golf tournament in a play-off against Louis Oosthuizen of South Africa with his mother Molly Watson at Augusta National Golf Club on April 8, 2012 in Augusta, Georgia. AFP PHOTO/Don EMMERT (Photo credit should read DON EMMERT/AFP/Getty Images), 97140=Bubba Watson hugs his caddie Ted Scott after winning the Masters golf tournament following a sudden death playoff on the 10th hole Sunday, April 8, 2012, in Augusta, Ga. (AP Photo/Chris O'Meara), 106602=Oosthuizen, the 2010 British Open champion, doesn't seem like a candidate to hit incredible shots - he's steady and stoic, almost the anti-Bubba. But little Louis smacked one of the most amazing shots in Masters history Sunday, on No. 2, a 575-yard downhill par-5 bending to the left., 104465=The outcome extended golf's wild free-for-all in recent years, a striking contrast with the Woods-dominated era of 1997 through 2008. Fourteen different players have won the past 14 majors, a streak dating to Padraig Harrington's 2008 win in the PGA Championship., 95100=Louis Oosthuizen, of South Africa, and his caddie Wynand Stander react after Oosthuizen's double eagle two on the par 5 second hole during the fourth round of the Masters golf tournament Sunday, April 8, 2012, in Augusta, Ga. (AP Photo/Matt Slocum)}
textBeforeTable: Final leaderboard Oosthuizen's second shot was short, his chip shot ran long and his par putt curled past the hole. And that's how a true original named Bubba ended up wearing a green jacket at Augusta National. Or, as Watson said, "I can hit it straight. It's just easier seeing curves." "I told some of the guys, it's probably better that he had to move the ball rather than hit it straight," Fowler said. Watson used his gap wedge and estimated he hooked the shot about 40 yards to set up a routine par. Hooked on hook shots They stayed even for the final two holes of regulation and the first playoff hole. Watson blinked first, when his next drive drifted left, but he then hit the shot of the tournament - a low, rising hook out of the darkness and onto the green (he had 164 yards to the hole). Kuchar's eagle on No. 15 vaulted him into a tie for the lead, until Oosthuizen made birdie on the same hole (and Kuchar then stumbled with bogey on No. 16). All the while, Watson flew into another realm - stringing together four birdies, from No. 13 through No. 16, to pull even with Oosthuizen. He held a two-shot lead over Watson and Peter Hanson at the turn, but several other players lurked - including Mickelson, Kuchar, Westwood and Harrington. That made for a riveting home stretch, full of swaying emotion. "The
